sentences.sentence: Then one morning, exactly at sunrise, she suddenly showed herself.
And, after working with all this painstaking( 费尽心思的 ) precision( 精致的妆容 ), she yawned( 打呵欠 ) and said:
“Ah! I am scarcely( 刚刚 ) awake. I beg that you will excuse me. My petals( 花瓣 ) are still all disarranged( 不整齐的 ) . . .”
But the little prince could not restrain( 克制 ) his admiration:
“Oh! How beautiful you are!”
“Am I not?” the flower responded, sweetly. “And I was born at the same moment as the sun . . .”
The little prince could guess easily enough that she was not any too modest—but how moving—and exciting—she was!
“I think it is time for breakfast,” she added an instant later. “If you would have the kindness to think of my needs—”
And the little prince, completely abashed( 窘迫的 ), went to look for a watering can( 洒水壶 ) of fresh water.
So, he tended the flower.
So, too, she began very quickly to torment( 折磨 ) him with her vanity( 虚荣心 )—which was, if the truth be known, a little difficult to deal with.
One day, for instance, when she was speaking of her four thorns( 刺 ), she said to the little prince:
“Let the tigers come with their claws!”
“There are no tigers on my planet,” the little prince objected. “And, anyway, tigers do not eat weeds( 杂草 ).”
“I am not a weed( 杂草 ),” the flower replied, sweetly.
“Please excuse me . . .”
“I am not at all afraid of tigers,” she went on, “but I have a horror( 害怕 ) of drafts( 冷空气 ). I suppose you wouldn’t have a screen for me?”
“A horror( 害怕 ) of drafts( 冷空气 )—that is bad luck, for a plant,” remarked the little prince, and added to himself, “This flower is a very complex creature . . .”
“At night I want you to put me under a glass globe. It is very cold where you live. In the place I came from—”
But she interrupted herself at that point.
She had come in the form of a seed.
She could not have known anything of any other worlds.
Embarrassed( 尴尬的 ) over having let herself be caught on the verge( 边缘 ) of such a naive( 幼稚的 ) untruth, she coughed two or three times, in order to put the little prince in the wrong.
“The screen?”
“I was just going to look for it when you spoke to me . . .”
Then she forced her cough a little more so that he should suffer from remorse( 懊悔 ) just the same.
So the little prince, in spite of( 尽管 ) all the good will that was inseparable from his love, had soon come to doubt her.
He had taken seriously words which were without importance, and it made him very unhappy.
“I ought not to have listened to her,” he confided( 吐露 ) to me one day.
“One never ought to listen to the flowers. One should simply look at them and breathe their fragrance( 芳香 ). Mine perfumed( 使香气弥漫 ) all my planet.
But I did not know how to take pleasure in all her grace( 恩惠 ).
This tale of claws, which disturbed( 使烦恼 ) me so much, should only have filled my heart with tenderness( 温柔 ) and pity.”
And he continued his confidences:
“The fact is that I did not know how to understand anything! I ought to have judged by deeds and not by words.
She cast her fragrance( 芳香 ) and her radiance( 光芒 ) over me.
I ought never to have run away from her . . . I ought to have guessed all the affection that lay behind her poor little stratagems( 花招 ). Flowers are so inconsistent( 自相矛盾的 )!
But I was too young to know how to love her . . .”
I believe that for his escape he took advantage of( 利用 ) the migration( 迁徙 ) of a flock of( 一群 ) wild birds.
On the morning of his departure( 离去 ) he put his planet in perfect order.
He carefully cleaned out( 打扫 ) his active volcanoes( 火山 ).
He possessed two active volcanoes( 火山 ); and they were very convenient( 便利的 ) for heating his breakfast in the morning.
He also had one volcano( 火山 ) that was extinct( 不再活跃的 ).
But, as he said, “One never knows!” So he cleaned out( 打扫 ) the extinct( 不再活跃的 ) volcano( 火山 ), too.
If they are well cleaned out( 打扫 ), volcanoes( 火山 ) burn slowly and steadily, without any eruptions( 喷发 ).
Volcanic( 火山的 ) eruptions( 喷发 ) are like fires in a chimney.
On our earth we are obviously much too small to clean out( 打扫 ) our volcanoes( 火山 ).
That is why they bring no end of trouble upon us.
The little prince also pulled up( 拔出 ), with a certain sense of dejection( 沮丧 ), the last little shoots( 嫩芽 ) of the baobabs( 猴面包树 ).
He believed that he would never want to return.
But on this last morning all these familiar tasks seemed very precious( 珍贵的 ) to him.
And when he watered the flower for the last time, and prepared to place her under the shelter( 庇护所 ) of her glass globe, he realized that he was very close to tears.
“Goodbye,” he said to the flower.
But she made no answer.
“Goodbye,” he said again.
The flower coughed.
But it was not because she had a cold.
“I have been silly,” she said to him, at last. “I ask your forgiveness. Try to be happy . . .”
He was surprised by this absence of reproaches( 责备 ).
He stood there all bewildered( 迷茫的 ), the glass globe held arrested( 停止 ) in mid-air.
He did not understand this quiet sweetness.
“Of course I love you,” the flower said to him. “It is my fault that you have not known it all the while. That is of no importance.
But you—you have been just as foolish as I. Try to be happy . . . Let the glass globe be. I don’t want it any more.”
“But the wind—”
“My cold is not so bad as all that . . . The cool night air will do me good. I am a flower.”
“But the animals—”
“Well, I must endure( 忍受 ) the presence of two or three caterpillars( 毛虫 ) if I wish to become acquainted( 熟悉的 ) with the butterflies. It seems that they are very beautiful.
And if not the butterflies—and the caterpillars( 毛虫 )—who will call upon( 拜访 ) me? You will be far away . . .
As for the large animals—I am not at all afraid of any of them. I have my claws.”
And, naively( 天真地 ), she showed her four thorns( 刺 ).
Then she added:
“Don’t linger( 逗留 ) like this. You have decided to go away. Now go!”
For she did not want him to see her crying.
She was such a proud flower . . .

article_info.previous: “我”因为忙着修理发动机对小王子的问题敷衍了事，以致于小王子十分生气。对此“我”感到不知所措，不知道该如何才能安慰他。之后“我”也知道了小王子心心念着的那朵小花的故事。
article_info.share_words: “Don’t linger like this. You have decided to go away. Now go!” For she did not want him to see her crying. She was such a proud flower . . .

analysis: 原文对话中：“Oh! How beautiful you are!”可知，答案为B。

question.en: What was the flower afraid of?

analysis: 原文花儿说：“I am not at all afraid of tigers,” she went on, “but I have a horror of drafts...”所以她害怕冷空气，选C。

options.en: Because she had a sore throat..

options.cn: 因为她想把错归到小王子身上。
options.en: Because she wanted to put the little prince in the wrong.

analysis: 原文提到：Embarrassed over having let herself be caught on the verge of such a naive untruth, she coughed two or three times, in order to put the little prince in the wrong. 所以答案选C。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第5天
